sections.heading: Nano- and Micromotors for Cleaning Polluted Waters: Focused Review on
Hamed Eskandarloo, Arkaye Kierulf, Alireza Abbaspourrad*
sections.text: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, USA *Corresponding author: E–mail address: alireza@cornell.edu Tel.: (607) 255-2923

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text: Nano- and micromotors are machines designed to self-propel and—in the process of propelling themselves—perform specialized tasks like cleaning polluted waters. These motors offer distinct advantages over conventionally static decontamination methods, owing to their ability to move around and self-mix—which heightens the interaction between their active sites and target pollutants—thus improving their speed and efficiency, which could potentially decrease treatment times and costs. In the last decade, considerable research efforts have been expended on exploring various mechanisms by which these motors can self-propel and remove pollutants, proving that the removal of oil droplets, heavy metals, and organic compounds using these synthetic motors is possible. This review highlights recent progress in the design of these nano- and micromotors for cleaning polluted waters, and gives an overview of their structure, fabrication, and propulsion methods, with a special focus on the mechanisms by which they remove pollutants—namely, either by adsorption or by degradation. A fundamental understanding of these removal mechanisms, with their attendant advantages and disadvantages, can help researchers fine-tune motor design in the future so that technical issues can be resolved before they are scaled-up for a wide variety of environmental applications.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Water is a fundamental requirement for human survival. But in many parts of the world, providing access to clean water remains a difficult challenge. 1,2 The World Health Organization (WHO) has estimated that 1.2 billion people do not have access to safe drinking water. 3 As the world’s population rapidly grows, this limited supply of clean water can only diminish with increasing demand. Widespread contamination of the water supply complicates the problem further and presents an additional threat—contaminants such as heavy metals, pathogens, and other toxins may cause diseases and trigger health issues. 4,5 There is a need to find ways to extract these contaminants from water quickly in order to minimize their environmental impact and make the water safe and desirable for drinking purposes. With this in mind, scientists have expended considerable efforts in designing more effective ways to treat water, efforts which have resulted in a range of low-cost and energyefficient methods for the removal of different contaminants. 6-9 In particular, nanotechnology—a field that has advanced at such a rapid pace in the last few decades—has offered several alternatives or enhancements to traditional methods of water treatment. Today, synthetic nano- and micromotors have been designed that can transform energy from different sources into mechanical force and motion, enabling them to perform specialized tasks via different mechanisms. These novel motors—powered either by fuel or by fuel-free sources such as electric or magnetic fields, acoustics, or even light—have many potentially exciting applications. 10-13 They exhibit high power and speed, alongside precise movement control, ability to self-mix, and ease with which the motor’s surface can be modified and their properties be tuned—all of which characteristics have allowed them to be adapted by multidisciplinary fields for a wide variety of applications, from drug delivery and microsurgery to biosensors. 14-17 Recently, a number of studies have been published about the design and fabrication of nanoand micromotors specifically aimed at environmental applications like water purification. These new motor-based techniques rely on self-propelling motors for the efficient selfmixing of a contaminated solution that drastically speeds up disinfection. Solution mixing is critical for improving the efficiency and speed of many chemical procedures, including decontamination processes where quiescent conditions result in long operation times and low reaction efficiency. By self-mixing, these new nano- and micromotors can more efficiently remove pollutants such as oil droplets, heavy metals, and other organic compounds. Some good review papers focusing on the environmental applications of synthetic motors have already appeared in the literature. 18-21 There are, however, no papers that directly focus

sections.heading: Pollutant Removal
sections.text:
Adsorption. Adsorption is a widely used process for the removal of contaminants in water. 41,42 It is a multi-step procedure which requires, first, the transport of target pollutants from the aqueous phase to the surface of porous, solid particles and, second, the diffusion of these target pollutants into the interior. 43 Recently, researchers have developed synthetic nano- and micromotors for the removal of different types of pollutants from water based on the adsorption mechanism. The adsorption efficiency of these synthetic motors has been

studied for pollutants such as oil droplets, metal ions, and organic compounds, which are summarized below. Oil droplet capture. Oils are a major source of ocean and groundwater pollution. The presence of oils in wastewaters is usually a direct result of manufacturing processes used by various industries. In addition, every year, oil spillage accidents release millions of tons of oil into the ocean. To minimize their environmental impact, it is necessary to remove these oils. Using adsorption, researchers have demonstrated the use of micromotors to capture, transport, and remove oil droplets. For example, Wang’s group reported the fabrication of a self-assembled monolayer (SAM)-modified poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT)/Pt micromotor that can adsorb oily droplets through adhesion to its long-chain, self-assembled alkanethiol coating (Figure 2A). 22 Surfaces with super-hydrophobic properties have a tendency to repulse water while strongly interacting with nonpolar or oily liquids, which then strongly adhere to their textured interfaces. These PEDOT/Pt micromotors were propelled efficiently via the expulsion of O2 bubbles produced from one end of the tubes. Pt catalyzes the decomposition of H2O2 into H2O and O2, resulting in an O2-bubble propulsion system. The release of O2 gas from one end of the motor essentially propels them. Figure 2B shows a SAM-modified tubular micromotor that was fabricated by electroplating a PEDOT/Pt bilayer, followed by e-beam deposition of Au/Ni, and subsequent functionalization with SAM. A scanning electron microscopy (SEM) micrograph of the unmodified PEDOT/Pt micromotor is shown in Figure 2C. In this work, the effect of the alkanethiol chain length, polarity, and head functional group attached to the micromotor’s surface upon the nanomotor–oil interaction and the motor’s propulsion was tested. The ideal, super-hydrophobic, dodecanethiol-coated, tubular micromotor showed strong interaction with, and successful pickup and transport of, nonpolar or oily liquids in polluted water. The unmodified micromotor, by contrast, did not interact with oils well.

Aiming to improve the oil-capturing capability of motors, Wang’s group also produced a hydrogen bubble–propelled Janus micromotor. Based on the magnesium–water reaction, this motor can be propelled in seawater without an external fuel. 23 Figures 2D-E show the schematic of the hydrogen bubble–propelled, seawater-driven, Mg-based Janus micromotor. The Mg particles had an average size of ∼30 µm and were half-covered by e-beam evaporation with Ti, Ni, and Au layers to form the Janus micromotors (with the Ti layer providing good contact between the Mg surface and the Ni–Au layers). Upon immersion of the Mg-based micromotor into seawater, a spontaneous redox reaction occurred in the Mg half of the motor, oxidizing the Mg surface to reduce water to hydrogen bubbles: Mg(s) + 2H2O(aq) → Mg(OH)2(s) + H2(g) (1) While the quickly formed oxide passivation layer on the Mg half-surface can hinder the process, they found that the presence of the gold layer on the other half and chloride ions permit reactions to proceed (macro-galvanic corrosion and pitting corrosion processes),

subsequently resulting in the continuous formation of hydrogen bubbles to drive the micromotor. Such a seawater-driven micromotor eliminated the need for external fuel, and the modification of its outer gold patch with long-chain alkanethiols led to a superhydrophobic surface that works effectively in cleaning oil. Another group, Mou et al., developed a novel, magnetically modulated micromotor of single-layered, pot-like, MnFe2O4 hollow particles with an ability to directly remove oils from water (Figure 2F). 24 These micromotors were fabricated by a growing-bubble-templated nanoparticle assembly method. As presented in Figure 2G, in this method, the hydrophobic MnFe2O4/oleic acid (OA) nanoparticles inside the volatile oil droplet containing n-hexane and chloroform are driven to its surface (oil/water interface) because of the outward diffusion of chloroform and assembled into a dense particulate shell due to the hydrophobic surface interactions of MnFe2O4/OA nanoparticles. This dense MnFe2O4 particulate shell then bursts because the encapsulated oil continuously vaporizes into high-pressured gas bubbles that end up boring a single hole through the shell, forming an asymmetric pot-like MnFe2O4 motor. Figure 2H shows that the as-assembled MnFe2O4 micromotors had a typical pot-like structure with a hollow interior and a single open hole in the shell. It has been proposed that the propulsion of these micromotors is caused by the catalytically created O2 bubbles on the inner concave surface of the micromotor, which are then continuously ejected from the open hole. The pot-like, MnFe2O4 micromotor could autonomously move in water with both direction and velocity modulated by an external magnetic field. Additionally, it could directly remove oil pollutants without any further surface modification because of the hydrophobicity of its surface due to pre-existing oleic acid long chains. Metal Ion Removal. The industrial revolution has brought about a rise in heavy metal contamination in the environment to such an extent that the substantial accumulation of these toxins in living organisms and the ecosystem currently poses a major threat to human health. 44,45 In response, considerable research efforts have been spent to remove and detoxify metals like lead, cadmium, thallium, mercury, and arsenic. 46,47 Researchers have produced nano- and micromotors to effectively remove heavy metals by adsorption. For example, Sanchez’s group fabricated a self-propelling, graphene oxide (GOx)–based, tubular micromotor that can capture, transfer, and remove lead from polluted water via adsorption, and then can be washed clean of the metal so the micromotor can be reused (Figure 3A). 25 These GOx-based, multilayer micromotors were prepared using a typical template-directed electrodeposition method—which creates nano-sized layers of GOx, nickel, and platinum, each with a distinct function. These newly designed GOx micromotors were able to remove Pb (II) ions 10 times more efficiently than nonmotile GOx micromotors, reducing levels of Pb in water from 1000 ppb to below 50 ppb in 60 min. A different strategy using water-powered, ligand-modified micromotors for the effective chelation of toxic heavy metal ions from contaminated solutions was reported by Wang’s group. 26 As presented in Figures 3C-D, Janus micromotors were fabricated by functionalizing Mg/Au micromotors with a self-assembled monolayer of meso-2,3dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA), an excellent chelating agent for heavy metals. These Mg/Au micromotors were then characterized by SEM (Figure 3E), which showed a spherical Janus structure. These micromotors moved autonomously in biological matrices and complex environments containing surfactant and chloride, obviating the need for external fuel or costly Pt catalysts. It was shown that the DMSA-based Janus micromotors were efficient at removing Pb(II), Cd(II), and Zn(II) ions. The dynamic chelation process fitted best with the Langmuir model, which suggests a strong interaction between the heavy metals and the motor’s surface, forming a monolayer over it. The improved chelation efficiency has been ascribed to the continuous movement of these micromotors, which facilitates the mixing of the fluid and thus leads to better binding of the heavy metals to the motor surface. In practice, these chelating micromotors show 100% removal efficiency for the relatively high concentrations of these three metals, thus demonstrating significant promise for cleaning highly polluted solutions. Organic Compound Removal. Persistent organic pollutants (POPs)—because they are resistant to degradation by biological, chemical, or physical means and can be transported everywhere via water, air, or other media 48-50 —tend to bioaccumulate in the living tissues of species high up in the food chain, posing a risk to human health and wildlife. 51 For their removal, Orozco et al. manufactured reduced graphene oxide (rGO)–coated, SiO2–Pt, magnetic, Janus micromotors for the efficient removal of POPs, using 5-chloro-2-(2,4dichlorophenoxy) phenol (triclosan) and polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) as model pollutants. 27
These Janus micromotors are composed of a SiO2–rGO core shell, plus a

Aiming to remove a wide range of pollutants in water, Wang’s group designed selfpropelling, activated, carbon-based Janus micromotors that can move easily in environmental matrices and remove pollutants efficiently (Figures 4B-C). 28 Activated carbon is the most well-known and cost-effective adsorbent for contaminants, because of its high specific surface area and tunable pore structure and surface chemistry, and short intraparticle diffusion distance. This bubble-propelled, carbon-based Janus micromotor relies on the asymmetric deposition of a catalytic Pt layer on the surface of the activated carbon particles (Figure 4D). The authors believe that the rough surface of the activated carbon particle resulted in a microporous Pt structure that provided a highly catalytic layer, which then led to motion with a higher speed of 500 µm s -1 . The synergy between the fast propulsion produced by the catalytic motor and the high adsorption capacity of the activated carbon resulted in a highly improved removal efficiency. This system was shown to be able to efficiently remove azo-dye compounds, heavy metals, nitroaromatic explosives, and organophosphorus nerve agents.

sections.heading: Degradation
sections.text:
In contrast to the adsorption mechanism, researchers have also developed synthetic nano- and micromotors that use the degradation mechanism to remove organic pollutants from water. Different strategies have been used, which include H2O2-assisted, NaBH4-assisted, photocatalytic, and biocatalytic degradation, which are summarized below. H2O2-assisted. The decomposition of hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen can be exploited to propel a motor. However, it should also be realized that H2O2 itself is a strong oxidizing agent that has been used to degrade organic compounds. 52 Taking advantage of these facts, Wang’s group designed a new strategy and employed low levels of H2O2 to create

The template fabrication process resulted in 8 µm-long polymer/Pt microtubes that were effectively moved by the ejection of oxygen bubbles produced by the catalytic oxidation of H2O2 fuel at the inner Pt layer. The repetitive motion of multiple motors across a H2O2-activated polluted solution resulted in greatly improved mass transport— thus enhancing the decontamination efficiency while using lower peroxide concentrations, shorter decontamination times, and no need for external agitation—as compared to common decontamination processes for chemical warfare agents.

(Figure 5B). 30 The microtubular motors were made using roll-up nanotechnology to form Fe/Pt thin films. The Fe/Pt-based micromotors designed this way had double functionality within their structure, namely, an outer Fe layer for the in-situ production of Fe +2 ions that give the decontamination process a boost and, secondly, an inner Pt layer for self-propulsion. The mechanism of pollutant degradation was based on Fenton reactions which rely on the spontaneous acidic corrosion of the motor’s Fe metal surface in the presence of H2O2, which acts both as main fuel to drive these motors and as a reagent for the Fenton oxidation process. The improved mixing and release of iron ions facilitated by these self-propelling motors resulted in the removal of Rhodamine 6G ca. 12 times higher than when the Fenton reaction was carried out with non-propelling Fe rolled-up tubes. In an alternative approach, Hao et al. reported a hydrothermal procedure for fabricating a three-dimensional Prussian blue (PB)sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS)-reduced GO hydrogel. 31 The hydrogel they designed had powerful mechanical properties and good synergy between Prussian blue and hydrogel, which served directly as a self-propelling motor for pollutant removal in the presence of H2O2. As shown in Figure 5C, the motor catalyzes the breakdown of H2O2 to generate hydroxyl radicals and oxygen bubbles. The hydroxyl radicals act as oxidants for the degradation of organic pollutants, and the oxygen bubbles generated move the motor. In this study, Methylene Blue was chosen as a model organic pollutant to examine the micromotor’s catalytic efficiency. Sodium dodecyl sulfate served as a stabilizing agent that could improve mechanical properties. In addition, SDS can also lower the surface tension of oxygen bubbles and cause them to be released quickly from the hydrogel. Because the O2 bubbles are rapidly released, the hydrogel moves faster and • OH radicals are more quickly produced, enhancing the decontamination process. Recently, light-assisted motors have received much attention because light is a renewable energy source that does not require a physical connection to the motor and does not usually lead to any waste products. In addition, light-assisted motors allow for precise control of their movement and reaction. Heterogeneous photocatalysis, another type of AOP, occurs when light is absorbed by an oxide semiconductor such as TiO2. When TiO2 absorbs a photon with energy higher than the band gap energy, the negative electrons transfer from the valence band to the conduction band, leaving behind positive holes. Pollutant removal using enzymes offers a more natural, less toxic mechanism that is effective over a wide range of environmental pH’s and temperatures, and will not have a negative effect on the ecosystem. sections.heading: Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text:
In the last decade, researchers have demonstrated that nano- and microscale machines have remarkable capabilities for water purification. These new motor-based techniques rely on the use of self-propelling motors for the efficient mixing of a contaminated solution, which drastically quickens the disinfection procedure. The efficiency of these self-propelling nanoand micromotors has been demonstrated for the removal of different kinds of pollutants, including oil droplets, heavy metals, and organic compounds. This review has highlighted recent advances and challenges in the use of nano- and micromotors, with a special focus on the mechanisms by which they remove pollutants from water—namely, either by adsorption or by degradation. The adsorption mechanism can bring about (a) oil capture, based on the hydrophobic modification of the motor’s outer surface with long chains such as alkanethiols and oleic acid; (b) the removal of metal ions, based on the modification of the motor’s surface with a chelating agent such as DMSA or using adsorbent materials such as GOx; and (c) the removal of organic compounds, based on the use of adsorbent materials such as rGO and activated carbon. Removal of organic pollutants can be done either by adsorption or degradation. But unlike the adsorption mechanism, in which organic pollutants are just being transferred from one phase to another, the degradation mechanism actually destroys them. The degradation mechanism for the removal of organic compounds can follow several schemes: (a) H2O2-assisted degradation, which uses the strong oxidizing agent, H2O2, as propulsion medium that catalytically decomposes into hydroxyl radicals and oxygen bubbles that together degrade organic compounds and propel the motor; (b) NaBH4-assisted degradation, which uses Pd particles, in the presence of NaBH4 as reductant, to catalytically reduce organic pollutants; (c) photocatalytic degradation, which uses photocatalyst materials

While significant strides have been made in the last decade toward the fabrication and use of these nano- and micromotors for the efficient removal of a wide range of pollutants from aqueous solutions, further innovation is required before these machines can be used for practical applications. Current findings do not meet the demands of large-scale cleanups, and several issues related to their mechanisms have first to be resolved. For example, the lifetime of these synthetic nano- and micromotors are too short—due to parts of the machine’s body actually being quickly consumed by oxidation or other reactions as it performs decontamination. That some materials used in these motors are themselves toxic—adding instead of reducing pollution in the environment—is an irony that argues for the use of greener materials such as Zn or Mg in designing self-degrading and environmentally friendly motors. Removing these new motors post-decontamination is also another issue that has to be resolved, either by making self-degrading motors or incorporating magnetic materials such as Fe into them to facilitate their removal post-cleanup. Pilot studies on large polluted areas need to be conducted to demonstrate these motors’ consistency and effectiveness, and to determine which mechanism types are appropriate for which types of pollution. For example, viscous polluted waters can hamper the movement, and decrease the efficiency, of small motors whose speeds are low. In these cases, bubble-propelled motors, which have been shown to maintain propulsion even in natural environments, are preferable, especially if they are made larger. Highly turbid polluted waters can deactivate light-assisted motors—because light may not be able to penetrate water deeply—thus rendering this type of motor ineffective in this kind of environment. In addition, the presence of certain compounds in wastewater could chemically bond to some of these motors’ active surface sites, thereby deactivating them. And because some of these mechanisms require the use of expensive materials such as Au and Pt, their cost relative to traditionally static cleanup methods will also have to be taken into account. Future innovations in the manufacture of these synthetic motors, if they can resolve these shortcomings connected with their mechanisms, will have a tremendous impact on their environmental applications, and could pave the way to providing clean water for a greater number of people in many parts of the world.

metadata.abstractText: Nanoand micromotors are machines designed to self-propel and—in the process of propelling themselves—perform specialized tasks like cleaning polluted waters. These motors offer distinct advantages over conventionally static decontamination methods, owing to their ability to move around and self-mix—which heightens the interaction between their active sites and target pollutants—thus improving their speed and efficiency, which could potentially decrease treatment times and costs. In the last decade, considerable research efforts have been expended on exploring various mechanisms by which these motors can self-propel and remove pollutants, proving that the removal of oil droplets, heavy metals, and organic compounds using these synthetic motors is possible. This review highlights recent progress in the design of these nanoand micromotors for cleaning polluted waters, and gives an overview of their structure, fabrication, and propulsion methods, with a special focus on the mechanisms by which they remove pollutants—namely, either by adsorption or by degradation. A fundamental understanding of these removal mechanisms, with their attendant advantages and disadvantages, can help researchers fine-tune motor design in the future so that technical issues can be resolved before they are scaled-up for a wide variety of environmental applications.
